content: The Act is titled the "Internet Gambling Study Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. The Congress finds that gambling is primarily regulated by State and tribal governments, with outdated Federal statutes on interstate wagering. The number of Americans gambling online has significantly increased, accounting for a large portion of the global market. Despite challenges, Congress recently passed the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act to address unlawful online gambling activities. It is crucial for Congress to establish safeguards in this evolving landscape. Congress must focus on establishing safeguards against gambling by minors, compulsive gambling, fraud, money laundering, and other forms of abuse. Legal experts are concerned about whether certain Federal and State gambling laws violate trade agreements. The ruling by the World Trade Organization could impact parties beyond the United States and Antigua and Barbuda. The purpose of this Act is to have a detailed examination by the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences on the issues related to the spread and growth of gambling. The curr_chunk discusses the impact of the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act on Internet gambling in the United States. SEC. 3. COMPREHENSIVE STUDY OF INTERNET GAMBLING. The National Research Council will conduct a study on Internet gambling, including the legal framework and the impact of the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act in the United States. The study will review laws at various levels of government and assess the proliferation of Internet gambling. The study on Internet gambling will include an analysis of its availability and use in the United States, its impact on minors and compulsive gamblers, as well as its use by terrorists and criminal enterprises for fraud and money laundering. It will also assess the impact of the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act. The study will analyze the impact of the Internet Gambling Enforcement Act on Internet gambling in the United States, including adverse effects, technological innovations, international practices, and federalism issues related to illegal Internet gambling. The curr_chunk discusses the international nature of online gambling and the potential for State and tribal governments to regulate it. It also addresses the problems of unregulated international Internet gambling and the potential for international cooperation. Additionally, it analyzes the impact of World Trade Organization rulings on Internet gambling and its effects on US trade agreements. The National Research Council will submit a comprehensive report on the findings and conclusions of potential tax revenue from legal Internet gambling in the US to the President, Congress, State Governors, and Native American tribal governments within 12 months.
